title: rund - Display font
content:
Hey guys,

I recently finished a display font. It is called rund which is Swedish for round.  
It is based on 12 circles laid out on a 3x4 grid.

It comes with a PDF poster that follows a similar 3-column grid, with the main copy laid out as the 3x4 grid used for the font. The color scheme is based on hue increments of 30, going from 0 to 360, thus completing the whole color wheel/circle.

It is downloadable for free from my site [| you can get it here](http://web.archive.org/web/20150416052825/http:/www.andersorrberg.com/index.php?/personal/rund---display-font/)

Let me know what you think.  
Hope you enjoy it.  
/Anders

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150416052825im_/http:/typophile.com/files/rund_1_5483.jpg)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150416052825im_/http:/typophile.com/files/rund_2_4129.jpg)
author: andersOrrberg

comments.content:
It has some interesting shapes. I like the flow of the characters. The z, q & x mess with me, but I see no other alternatives considering the constraints of the design. My biggest problem is, from a sign design stand point, that it is too weak. It would get lost in the negative space from any distance at all. Still looks cool.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~

[_...from the Fontry_](http://web.archive.org/web/20150416052825/http:/www.thefontry.com/)

Thanks for the feedback.

Yeah, some problems can't be avoided, following the constraints of the grid.

You're right, it wouldn't work on a sign, it wasn't really intended to do that either though. It might be a bit too weak in general but I quite liked it being so thin. I have been considering making a few other weights though, which would extend the possible areas where it could be used.

It works best in printed media and in fairly large point size on screen.

/A

I could see it used on a sign or poster ad in a mall for an artsy boutique, even as light as it is.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~
